title: Who will be elected governor of Georgia in the 2018 election?
preds: With Kemp trying so desperately to suppress Democrat votes and given he controls the voting and the vote counting and his willingness to win at all cost and given Georgia's voting systems are notorious for their unreliability and lack the ability to do audits, this will be a very tough election.  I doubt this election will be settled anytime soon.  If, miracles of miracles we get a fair count, Abrams will win.

Given Georgia's voting systems are very vulnerable to manipulation, probably the most vulnerable in the nation, and given Republicans have no boundaries when it comes to attaining and maintaining political power,  anything is possible in Georgia.  But by all appearances, Abrams should win a fair and honest election. The question is will it be a fair election?  Kemp, the guy running the election and the guy on the ballot has already been reprimanded twice by federal judges for illegal actions taken by him during this election.

ATLANTA - The Georgia Secretary of State’s Office says they are investigating a failed attempt to hack the state’s voter registration system by the Democratic Party of Georgia, the office said in a news release.  The state has not said what evidence they have that a hack occurred.  "While we cannot comment on the specifics of an ongoing investigation, I can confirm that the Democratic Party of Georgia is under investigation for possible cyber crimes," said Secretary of State office Press Secretary Candice Broce. "We can also confirm that no personal data was breached and our system remains secure." Bwa-Haaaaaaaa! Fraking cheaters..... but we already knew that.....sociofascists play by "rules for radicals."
Still gonna lose.
https://www.wsbtv.com/news/local/secretary-of-state-s-office-says-investigation-underway-into-hack-by-democratic-party/866298517 Death of 1000 cuts.

I looked at this election earlier in the year and was concerned with some of Abrams' personal issues, but it appears that she has been able to run good campaign. Having Oprah campaign for you is probably underrated too.

I consulted the I Ching oracle, so this is essentially a random response.
Stacey Abrams received hexagram 12, line 6: "overthrowing obstruction, first there is obstruction, then there is joy."
This looks good for Stacy Abrams.
Then I asked about Brian Kemp. He received hexagram 1, line 5: "flying dragons in the sky, great people working creatively."
This, on balance, favors Brian Kemp.
So I predict a close race with Brian Kemp coming out on top.
If one is to take this I Ching random selection seriously it is never a good idea to second guess a prediction.
If that is the case then Stacy Abrams is the successful candidate.
We'll see.

175 (4 today) from 104 43-57-0
Bet#3 40-60-0 now 1-99-0  Cooky Crook Kempy is in.
RPC Average Retrieved 10/28, transformed into a probability curve.
As cookoo as he sounds and crooked as he might be, the electorate in GA are comfortable with cukes  and crooks....
Larger than normal early voter turnout, recent State Supreme court decision favoring absentee and against non-identical 'perfect match' ballots, large increase in new registrants
Racist views that won't be expressed in polls will make the difference.
They will suppress the votes and Abrams flag burning will hurt her
Based on the FiveThirtyEight Governor Forecast

It's close, and Stacy Abrams seems to have gained momentum recently, but I still think the edge goes to Kemp. I think there might be a little bit of the Bradley effect in the poll numbers, even if it supposedly doesn't exist anymore: https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/if-bradley-effect-is-gone-what-happened/ The Bradley Effect: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bradley_effect
This is tough. If Kemp is successful in his attempts to suppress voters, he may win. But I'm betting on Abrams.

Mr. Kemp appears to have a history of less than ethical conduct as secretary of state in his role of running elections and is still currently in charge of the election he is competing in. These circumstances would lead one to believe, given the current vulnerability of elections in the u.s. and abroad, that Mr. Kemp stands the greatest chance of winning.

It will be Kemp  unless the court keep him from destroying the democratic process. If he is elected while allowing voter suppression, the entire election will be thrown into the courts and will not be resolved four months perhaps Longer
Georgia is in transition. The young and newcomers to the state will change it.
Flags and indicators I'm looking for involve Hurricane relief response.

Shifting a few points toward Kemp because he is maintaining a small but persistent lead. Given the fundamentals of Georgia I think the republicans maintain more of an edge in the state but we will see if Abrams can activate new voters.

despite the 50,000 or so frozen voter registrations 200,000 additional voters have been added to the voter rolls (~3% increase). This nudges some advantage back to Abrams, as these new voters are likely young and/or minorities.
using R-model. Somehow haven't updated this in 2 weeks.
Weighted average of forecasters I follow.
Gah.   To be ahead of the crowd, I have to choose higher.  Tolerable risk, I suppose.
year of the woman 2.0 and Kemp is far too attached to Trump

Was 49-51 now 40-60 
Only 73 from 56 with crowd at 45-55

The candidates are about even right now. Additionally, the dems polling margin on the generic ballot is decreasing as we approach election day, meaning that Abrams is likely to only weaken from this point on. Main unknown that I can't figure out is how well Abrams is doing registering voters. it's also hard to tell how energizing the historic-ness of Abrams's candidacy will energize her base. If we just fall back on priors, we'd predict Kemp with very high certainty, given what we know from the polling Abrams chance improves quite a bit, but I'd say odds still favor Kemp. Things will move based on new polls/scandals/ information about Abrams's get out the vote efforts.
It is just a close call; edge to Republicans given it is Georgia
Kemp is ahead with only 2 points in one poll, consistent with what the polls would say at the end of September.

Abrams is dogged by questions of millions of dollars of donations that were applied to her personal credit cards.    Effective political ads.  With the republican slightly ahead, and usually lower mid term voting patterns, with small numbers of undecided - I tink Kemp has this.
Voter anger, esp. among women and minorities, favor the black woman over the white guy in this round.

Ms Abrams is running a grass roots campaign. Getting supporters to the polls is the key to victory for her. She has the wind behind her because she is not mincing words. People know exactly where she stands on each issue.
It will come down to likely voters vs. eligible voters. Abrams is a great candidate, but the GOP will actually vote.

I think Abrams is a a strong candidate with deep political experience in the state thanks to her role as house minority leader and I have read that she excels at retail politics. Despite that inside perspective and information, the stats has had republican governors since 2003 and the state has been trending more and more republican. Point I think between polling and fundamentals that Kemp is the slight favorite but Abrams has a strong chance.

Polls have them even, but not many have been conducted recently.
The only edge I'm giving to Kemp is the incumbency effect. Otherwise, it's pretty even.
Updates to follow.

Unless Brian Kemp makes a grave mistake (hence a 10% chance), Kemp should win this. Poll in September for many cycles in Georgia always have the Dems in the lead or tie, but when comes November, GOP win by 6-8 points.  While there are more and more relocations from California or New York, the balance may not tip in favor of Dems just yet.
The Republicans will squeeze one more victory out of GA  with the help of a great deal of voter suppression. It will be close.

Former U.S. President Jimmy Carter (D) hit the campaign trail with Stacey Abrams, the Democratic gubernatorial nominee in Georgia. Carter and Abrams campaigned in Plains, Georgia, the former president’s hometown, and discussed rural healthcare. Abrams says she would expand Medicaid in Georgia to shore up the rural healthcare system.
Abrams, a former state representative, faces Secretary of State Brian Kemp (R) in the general election. On Tuesday, the Democratic Party of Georgia released an ad criticizing Kemp for not giving a detailed healthcare plan on his website. Kemp has expressed opposition to expanding Medicaid but said he would be open to obtaining a waiver from the federal government to stabilize premiums.
Kemp went on his own tour of rural Georgia this week. He visited Albany in southwest Georgia Sunday and spoke about the need to expand rural broadband.
A lot of positive news about Abrams.   Too little support for Kemp.   Kemp is Trump's  guy and will be strained with the same brush.
I believe the "non-white" folks will go to the polling booths in droves to elect the first African American governor in Georgia.

This is not going to be as close as current predictions would indicate.  The Republican vote in this election will exceed current predictions as many normally nonvoters will show up and casts votes for the Republican ticket as happen two years ago

Too close to call, but what the heck. White right man beats out black woman. Is Georgia like neighbouring states with near-majority of black people?  Is GA ready for a black woman guv?
